title: Open data. Agent of change.
body:
The most successful open data initiatives share similar characteristics that shape organisations and individuals and prepares them to unlock the value that open data provides to new markets.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • Open data as an agent of change
  • Leadership and Engagement
  • Supply and Demand
  • Culture change for new markets

title: Engaging in open data initiatives – in two minutes
displayTitle: Engaging in open data initiatives – in two minutes
body: The ODI’s Liz Carolyn explains the top 5 characteristics of successful open data initiatives and how open data requires us to think differently about the way the market for data functions.

title: Open data. Agent of Change.
body:
Implementing an open data initiative involves cultural and institutional change.

Open data is not just about putting data on a website under and open licence. Technology is the easy part, cultural change is much harder and more important.

The web has evolved from a tool into a way of thinking. It has changed the fundamental way in which people interact. Open data is on the same path.

title: Leadership and Engagement
body: Active leadership and engagement leads to successful initiatives and positive change.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Active Leadership
_items.body:
As an open data programme is launched, it is common for the people driving the change to encounter some resistance from within the organisation.

The active support of senior figures helps to overcome resistance.

Senior figures have an active role in embedding broader changes into organisations by adopting new values and attitudes to open data.

_items.title: Active Engagement
_items.body:
Engagement with civil society, business and government is a crucial part of the process of open data initiatives.

Successful initiatives start with open dialogue between the publisher and the consumer of open data.

This dialogue is important for both publisher and consumer of open data to understand the demand and opportunity.

_graphic.alt: A graph of open licences across countries
_graphic.title: A graph of open licences across countries

_items.title: Space to innovate
_items.body:
Strong leadership and active engagement with key stakeholders is critical to a successful initiative.

Active leadership delivers a 'push' from the organisation, active dialogue creates a 'pull' from the users.

This unlocks innovation opportunities by connecting problems to potential solutions where open data is key.

_graphic.alt: A map from a to b
_graphic.title: A map from a to b

title: Supply and Demand
body:
Publish and be thanked!

When examining an open data initiative, consider the following:

_items.title: Approach
_items.body:
To date, a large number of open data initiatives have taken the approach of ‘build a portal, publish data, publish better data and hope that it is what consumers want or needed’.

With maturity in the open data community, a lot of people are now adopting the approach of taking the perspective of the consumer and clarifying the benefits they could get from the data.

A staged approach helps ensure that an organisation walks before it runs and achieves change in small, noticeable steps, rather than aim for the sky and end up with nothing.

_items.title: Demand
_items.body:
There is little point in publishing data in the public domain if there is no-one prepared or incentivised to use the data and create new value from it.

It is best to focus on demand where it currently exists.

Use consumer dialogues, opinion surveys or ‘vox pops’ already conducted to see where the most interest lies and follow it.

Think about the problems that already exist and how you relate to them. Data is a tool.

_items.title: Community
_items.body:
A successful open data initiative has a thriving community, with clear and accessible resources that support the data and its use.

A sign of a strong community is one that feels a real sense of ownership. This ownership should cover both the data and the outputs generated.

In is essential for both publishers and consumers to fully understand the others perspective.

This is how to replicate the Raspberry-Pi project for data?
Take me to the Raspberry-Pi project

title: Culture change for new markets
body: Technology is the easy part.  Identifying new markets and implementing culture change is much harder.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: New markets
_items.body:
The traditional ‘market’ for open data in which government published data and others consume it has fundamentally changed in recent years.

Government, civil society and business all now find themselves simultaneously in the position of supplier and consumer of open data.

_items.title: Culture change
_items.body:
Open data requires a change in the way an institution operates.

People driving initiatives need to spend time developing a shared vision, overcoming barriers and building coalitions for change.

Consumers should be ready to engage with open data as a core part of society.

Open data is already demonstrating that it could have the same impact on society that the web has.

_items.title: Planning for change
_items.body:
How to handle and plan for culture change is still being defined.

Governments, organisations and individuals should have free access to key education, tools and guides that help plan for the future.

Pilots and practical initiatives play important roles in understanding the impact of open data and the change process. Observations from such initiatives can also inform practical guides like the ODIs Open Data Pathway.

title: Open data.  Agent of Change.
body:
Implementing an open data initiative involves cultural and institutional change.

Engagement with civil society, business and government is an important part of the process.

With maturity in the open data community, a lot of people are now adopting the approach of taking the perspective of the consumer.

Open data requires us to think differently about the way the market for data functions.

In the next module, we look at simplifying open data licences.
